journal-meta.journal-title: Transactions of the Institute of Measurement and Control

title-group.article-title: Analysis and control of a high-purity distillation column system

article-meta.aff: 1Islamic Azad University (IAU), South Tehran Branch, Tehran, Iran
2Islamic Azad University (IAU), Lahijan Branch, Lahijan, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Amir Hooshang Mazinan, Islamic Azad University (IAU), South Tehran Branch, No. 317, Floor 5, Entrance 4, Block 19, Phase 2, Ekbatan Complex, Tehran 1395713811, Iran Email: mazinan@azad.ac.ir

abstract.p: This research work looks at methods for controlling a two-phase distillation column system. The present system consists of a vertical column with a number of trays used for component separation. It also has a reboiler and a condenser; these are used to provide heating and cooling for vaporization and condensation, respectively. The proposed control scheme uses the model-based predictive control (MBPC) scheme with the internal model being produced by a set of Takagi Sugeno Kang (TSK) fuzzy-based models. The internal set of TSK fuzzy-based models are developed from a linear models predictive approach. That is, it makes a prediction of the present system using a set of TSK fuzzy-based models identified, at each instant of time. The control scheme is then evaluated using simulation and compared with a benchmark fuzzy-based PI control scheme. The novelty of the present research is to propose a new organization in system modeling and its control scheme by combining the MBPC scheme and artificial intelligence (AI)-based techniques for the purpose of improving the system performance results.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: A two-phase distillation column system consists of a vertical column with a number of trays in association with a reboiler and a condenser for the purpose of providing component separation in both academic and real domains. The reboiler and the condenser are organized to provide the heat for appropriate vaporization from the bottom of the column and to provide the cooling for appropriate liquidization from the top of the column, respectively. In order to hold the condensed vapor to recycle liquid reflux from the top of the column, a reflux drum is also realized in this system. The present distillation column system may be organized based on a number of inputs flows including feed rate (liquid), boil-up flow (vapor), and reflux flow (liquid), respectively. A number of parameters including distillate bottom product flow rate and distillate top product flow rate are also taken as system outputs. Hereinafter, two-product compositions have to be dealt with through appropriate control schemes, i.e. the distillate product composition and the bottom product composition. In fact, these compositions require an efficient control algorithm to be dealt with at each instance of time.

Regarding the present system, a number of publications are available in which this system, in its general form, has been taken into consideration as a controlled process (Skogestad and Morari 1988; Skogestad 1997; Kano et al. 2000; Rueda et al. 2005; Savkovic-Stevanovic 2005; Nagy et al. 2007; Chen et al. 2009; Guo et al. 2009; Minh and Muhamad 2010) Skogestad (1997) proposed a LV -configuration control for a high-purity distillation column, where Minh and Muhamad (2010) used the MBPC scheme for controlling a condensate distillation column, as well. In this regard, Skogestad and Morari (1988) described a fundamental control idea for the present system. Also, Savkovic-Stevanovic (2005) suggests a neural-fuzzy system for the purpose of dealing with an ethanol recovery distillation, where Nagy et al. (2007) uses a output feedback through nonlinear model predictive control for tracking the temperature, in an industrial batch reactor. Guo et al. (2009) proposed multiple multivariable MBPC in the area of the system presented here. Rueda et al. (2005) suggested a nonlinear predictive control solution for the present distillation column system, while Kano et al. (2000) realizes an inferential control system using dynamic partial least squares regression for distillation compositions. It is obvious from Skogestad and Morari (1988), Minh and Muhamad (2010), Rueda et al. (2005), Kano et al. (2000), Skogestad (1997), Savkovic-Stevanovic (2005), Nagy et al. (2007), Guo et al. (2009), and Chen et al. (2009) that the distillation column needs to be represented using mathematical relations from which the various control strategies described may be realized. The present MBPC could be used to control a distillation column system. A particularly attractive control, in the MBPC family, is now known as the LGPC scheme. This is the control scheme we realize in this research work, due to its facility and efficiency in the field of process control. Based upon LGPC scheme realization, it needs to be assumed that a CARIMA model has to be identified as the best representation of the system. It should be noted that CARIMA model identification actually needs to be identified prior to realizing the LGPC scheme.

The main goal of the present paper is to develop a novel control scheme for a distillation column that combines AI-based techniques with the MBPC scheme. In order to describe all of the control elements in the proposed strategy, at first, a TSK fuzzy-based predictive approach needs to be realized to identify an appropriate model of the column system. In fact, the proposed TSK fuzzy-based predictive approach is realized to make an accurate prediction of the system, once the LGPC scheme is correspondingly designed. In the area of related research works, many publications are available regarding the combination of an LGPC approach and a number of AI-based techniques. In line with the matter presented here, a TSK fuzzy-based model is used to represent a number of linear time invariant plants (described by ARIMAX models) for the purpose of dealing with an LGPC scheme (Hadjili and Wertz 1999) The research of Hadjili and Wertz (1999) presents an efficient control algorithm in dealing with the system parameters, but is not applied for a specific industrial process to be taken into account, as a practical control method. The present LGPC scheme using RFNN is also realized for industrial systems (Chi-Huang and Ching-Chih 2007). The work of Chi-Huang and Ching-Chih (2007) presents a design methodology for predictive control of a physical variable-frequency oil-cooling machine via RFNNs.

In this research, a discrete-time mathematical model and also a RLS learning algorithm are realized to identify the model unknown parameters. In such a case, LGPC scheme with integral action is designed based upon the minimization of a performance criterion, where the stability and steady-state performance of the control system are appropriately resulted. In the area of system presented here, a TSK fuzzy-based model, in an off-line manner, is realized to combine with an LGPC scheme to control a system (Qiang et al. 2006). This method uses both a fuzzy-based approach and a weighted recursive least-squares (RLS) method to identify a TSK fuzzy-based model, in its off-line form. After that, this identified model is realized with an LGPC scheme to control nonlinear systems. Hereinafter, a fuzzy-based model predictive control is investigated for a nonlinear system, using GA, where a TSK fuzzy-based model is given, as a predictor of the system behavior, in order to organize its control scheme (Sarimveis and Bafas 2003). In such a case, we can see a constrained predictive control in accordance with TSK fuzzy-based model for a nonlinear system (Bail et al. 2007). In this solution, at first, a TSK fuzzy-based model in association with the fuzzy-based clustering algorithm and also the orthogonal least-squares method is realized to represent a nonlinear system. Afterwards, in order to realize this model, an LGPC scheme, with input constraints, is described. A multiple fuzzy-based model temperature predictive control is given for a nonlinear system, as well (Ming et al. 2005). In another case, an LGPC scheme, using artificial neural network plant model, is given to handle a bio-process, as a realistic nonlinear system (Rusnak et al. 1996), while this scheme, using a multi-layer feed-forward neural network, is also suggested as a nonlinear model for the purpose of dealing with a complex system (Soloway and Haley 1997). Hereinafter, an LGPC scheme in association with the multi-layer feed-forward neural network, as a model of the nonlinear system, is investigated (Chidrawar et al. 2009). As is obvious from the present research works, each one of them proposes a specific method to realize an LGPC scheme for a nonlinear system. In fact, these control solutions are all investigated to cope with the system through an LGPC scheme.

The main differences between the proposed strategy and specially those obtained from Hadjili and Wertz (1999), Chi-Huang and Ching-Chih (2007), Qiang et al. (2006) and Sarimveis and Bafas (2003) are twofold. In this paper, first the prediction of the system behavior is accurately made through a set of TSK fuzzy-based models, using a so-called fuzzy-based predictive approach, where the nonlinearity of the system could actually be dealt with. Subsequently, an LGPC scheme is organized in a novel manner, through the proposed approach, to support the present system modeling approach. It should be noted that the limitations of the surveyed researches may be taken into account in the type of realizations and corresponding concepts, in our point of view. This means that a number of them are all organized in line with standard control schemes to deal with the present system, where AI-based techniques in accordance with the control theories are realized to organize some other control methods, in an efficient manner. In these cases, the second control methods are efficiently realized to deal with the system in comparison with the first, in which the wide range of system operating points could be abruptly varied, at each instance of time. As is obvious here, the control scheme, in the present research, falls into the second category. Owing to the fact that the proposed control scheme is configurable by choosing a number of TSK fuzzy-based models, which are used in the proposed TSK fuzzy-based predictive approach, its efficiency with respect to each other could be taken into real consideration. In fact, this facility aims to organize a configurable control scheme, once we are faced with a highly complex system, at each instance of time. In other words, the complexity of the proposed control scheme could correspondingly be increased, while complex systems are used to control. Moreover, it is also shown that this complexity could be decreased, while simple linear or nonlinear systems are chosen. In the same way, the proposed control scheme could easily be realized to deal with a number of real systems, because of the fact that the present adjustable control method is easy to realize in accordance with the model of the system. As a result, the advantage of the proposed control scheme with respect to related schemes is that it deals with a wide range of highly nonlinear systems, provided that their CARIMA representations of the system could accurately be identified. This means that the present method is easy to reorganize by changing the system from one to another. Also, the performance of the proposed method is efficient for each one of the chosen systems, at each instance of time, owing to its facility in identifying the system behavior through AI-based techniques in association with the powerful control theory, i.e. an LGPC scheme.

The remainder of the present paper is organized as follows. The distillation column system is given in Section 2. The proposed AI-based control scheme is given in Section 3. Finally, the simulation results and the concluding remarks are presented in Sections 4 and 5, respectively.

sec.title: The distillation column system
sec.p: A distillation column system, which is shown in Figure 1, also now known as a popular separation process, is used to purify final products. This system may be made up of several components, which are all used to transfer heat energy in line with purification of the products. This system contains a vertical column with a number of trays to enhance the component separations.

caption.p: A schematic of the distillation column system.

sec.p: In such a case, a reboiler is used to provide the heat for appropriate vaporization from the bottom of the column, where a condenser is also used to provide the cooling for appropriate liquidization from the top of the column. Afterwards, a reflux drum is used to hold the condensed vapor to recycle liquid reflux from the top of the column. The relationship between liquid composition and vapor composition is given by

A two-phase distillation column system has a number of inputs flows including VB=V, LD=L, D and B, respectively. In this regard, L and V are known as the internal flows, where D and B are also known as the external flows, in the present system. Hereinafter, two-product compositions have to be dealt with through their control schemes, i.e. xD and xB. There is a number of combinations of these internal/external flows to realize some standard configurations, including LV, DV, DB and (L/D)(V/B), for this system. Under the LV configuration, which is investigated in this research work, L and V, as the independent variables, are followed by
where glvij represents the following:

list-item.p: The effect of a variation in L on xD under constant V (i=j=1).
The effect of a variation in V on xD under constant L (i=1 and j=2).
The effect of a variation in L on xB under constant V (i=2 and j=1).
The effect of a variation in V on xB under constant L (i=j=2).

sec.p: In such a case, by assuming that V is a constant value, i.e. dV=0, we can note from Equation (2.2) as dxD=glv11dL. In the same way, by controlling xB as a constant value, i.e. dxB=0, we can yield the following dV=−glv21glv22dL from the same equation. Afterwards, the outcomes could be rewritten as
As a consequence, once L is used to control the xD, it is appropriate to note that the effect of L on xD does not depend on the control of the xB.
In order to present the system modeling, the following assumptions first need to be made:

list-item.p: Vapor–liquid equilibrium on all stages (same vapor flow).
Constant liquid holdup, i.e. negligible flow dynamics.

sec.p: With these assumptions, the results on each tray including reboiler (i=1), feed trays (i=2 to nt−1) and condenser (i=nt) are given by

In order to realize the control strategy proposed here, in the next section of the present paper we need to identify the linearized models of the system. With this purpose, the investigated results, at steady state, could be written as
In such a case, we have the following:
The linear model of the system is investigated by slight variations at steady state as
where λB and λi are given as ΔyBΔxB and ΔyiΔxi and we define the following
As is obvious, the outcomes are in the form of state space equations, which could be expressed by the following:
where the following notation is used x=[xB,xi,xnf,xj,xD]T,u=[LD,VB]T,d=[F,zF]T, i=2,…,nf−1 and finally j=nf+1,…,nt−1, respectively.

sec.title: The proposed AI-based control scheme
sec.p: The proposed AI-based control scheme is investigated in association with the TSK fuzzy-based predictive approach, which is organized in line with a set of TSK fuzzy-based models as well as LGPC scheme, realized through this approach, as shown in Figure 2 (Li et al. 2004; Mollov et al. 2004; He et al. 2005; Rueda et al. 2005; Palm 2007; Su et al. 2007; Mazinan and Sadati 2008; Nandola and Bhartiya 2008; Mazinan and Hosseini 2010; Mazinan and Kazemi 2010a,b; Mazinan and Sadati 2010a,b,c; Mazinan and Kazemi 2011; Mazinan and Sadati 2011).

In order for the implementation of the control strategy, the proposed TSK fuzzy-based predictive approach first has to be realized. In fact, the system could appropriately be identified through the proposed approach, while the system behavior is abruptly varied, at each instance of time. With this purpose, this model is realized using the number of IF–THEN rules and the corresponding input–output fuzzy sets, respectively. Assuming that y(k−p) (p=0,1,…,n−1) and u(k−q) (q=0,1,…,m−1) are given as input/output of the system and ψ≧2 is assumed, the ith (i=1,2,…) model rule could then be investigated by the following
TSKFBM#1i IF y(k) is SOFSi THEN
TSKFBM# ψi IF y(k) is SOFSi THEN
where SOFS is shown in Figure 3.

caption.p: The fuzzy sets used in the proposed TSK fuzzy-based predictive approach.

sec.p: Regarding the number of fuzzy sets used in the present SOFS, they are all dependent on the range of system output variation and its accuracy, directly. It should be noted that the performance of the proposed control scheme could efficiency be increased by employing the large number of the fuzzy sets, while the realization of the control method is correspondingly complicated. In fact, we need to find the optimal number of the system output fuzzy sets to be realized here. Since the performance of the proposed method could not be increased, by increasing these fuzzy sets in number, in a corresponding manner, the optimal number could easily be calculated. In this regard, by choosing the correct number, the minimum complexity of the proposed approach in the maximum efficiency could be acquired. Regarding the terms of Equation (3.2), as ECARIMA representation of the system, it is better to note that these terms are extended results of Equation (3.1), as CARIMA representations of the system. In such a case, the first and the second terms of Equation (3.2) are related to the first term of Equation (3.1), while the third and the fourth terms are also related to the second term of the present one. In fact, it is easy to follow how to extend Equation (3.1) through Equation (3.2) by making a long-range system prediction. Based upon these formulations, this TSK fuzzy-based predictive approach could be realized, as the best representation of the system, at each instance of time. Now, the proposed TSK fuzzy-based predictive approach could be organized as
where

It should be noted that Equations (3.3), (3.4) and (3.5) are all realized through the centroid defuzzification and the product inference, as a standard defuzzifier, in the area of fuzzy logic approach.

In such a case, the results for the multiple-input multiple-output system, i.e. η=1,2 could be rewritten as an extended version by the following. In this regard, the system inputs are given as VB and LD, where system outputs are taken as xD and xB, respectively.
TSKFBM#1i : IF yη(k) is ηSOFSi THEN
To handle a multivariable system, the investigated results should be generalized by the following:
TSKFBM# ψi: IF yη(k) is ηSOFSi THEN
where

It could also be shown that the exact number of the SOFSs employed in this method is equivalent to the number of system outputs. As is obvious from the system presented here, based upon the number of controlled outputs, two SOFSs need to be realized. In the control strategy presented, the LGPC scheme has to be realized in correspondence with the TSK fuzzy-based predictive approach.

sec.title: The simulation results
sec.p: In order to consider the suitability of the proposed control schemes, the present distillation column system has been dealt with, as mentioned before, in this paper. In this simulation, its parameters are first given by
Also, the TSK fuzzy-based predictive approach is organized by

In the same way, the parameters ap (p=0,1,…,n−1) and bq (q=0,1,…,m−1) are directly identified through the RLS identification algorithm, as CARIMA and ECARIMA representations of the system, which are all tabulated in Table 1.

caption.p: The coefficients of CARIMA and ECARIMA used in the proposed TSK fuzzy-based predictive approach.

sec.p: In the control strategy proposed here, the system outputs, i.e. xD, xB are given by yη(k) (η=1,2), respectively. Also, their control actions for these parameters are correspondingly given by uη(k) (η=1,2). In these simulations, the desired xD is given by the following in 1200 seconds, while the desired xB is assumed to be constant as 0.01 throughout the simulation time:

In the same way, Figures 4 and 5 show the xD and xB tracking performance, through the PIBC scheme. In this way, the first is under the present desired xD variation and also the second is under the constant desired xB, respectively. In order to verify the distillation column performance, all of the outcomes regarding the compositions on trays are just given in Figures 6–11.

caption.p: The xD tracking performance of the PIBC scheme.
The xB tracking performance of the PIBC scheme.

sec.p: Also, the manipulated variables and their control actions in the case of xD and xB are given in Figures 12–15. For the purpose of analyzing the proposed control scheme validity, its results are just compared with the traditional fuzzy-based PI control scheme, as the benchmark approach, the parameters of which are easily acquired, through a standard fuzzy rule-based system. As is obvious, in Figures 16 and 17, the investigated results of the PIBC scheme are appropriately outperformed with respect to the previous scheme. Finally, to gain an appropriate sense of showing the PIBC scheme in comparison with the FPIC scheme, Figures 18 and 19 are provided. The FPIC scheme outcomes are also shown in the same figures, in a synchronized manner, with respect to the PIBC scheme.

caption.p: The xD tracking performance of the FPIC scheme.
The xB tracking performance of the FPIC scheme.
The xD tracking performance of the PIBC scheme in comparison with the FPIC scheme.
The xB tracking performance of the PIBC scheme in comparison with the FPIC scheme.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: A study of an AI-based predictive control scheme has been presented in this paper that deals with a distillation column system. The present system is known as an appropriate separation process. It is organized based on a vertical column with a number of trays for the purpose of enhancing the component separations. In the area of the proposed AI-based control scheme, namely PIBC scheme, a realization of TSK fuzzy-based predictive approach is realized to organize the appropriate model of the system and also its control scheme, in an efficient manner. It is shown that the present TSK fuzzy-based predictive approach is realized to make a desirable prediction of the system to cope with the corresponding control scheme. Finally, the results are compared with the traditional fuzzy-based PI control scheme.

app.title: Abbreviations:
app.p: MBPC Model-based predictive control
LGPC Linear generalized predictive control
RLS Recursive least squares
CARIMA Controlled auto-regressive integrated moving average
ECARIMA Extended CARIMA
AI Artificial intelligence
TSK Takagi Sugeno Kang
SOFS System output fuzzy set
PIBC Proposed intelligence-based control
FPIC Fuzzy-based PI control
RFNN Recurrent fuzzy neural networks

LV
Liquid vapor

DV
Distillate vapor

DB
Distillate bottom

( L / D ) ( V / B )
Liquid/distillate vapor/bottom

ack.p: We would like to express all our best wishes to the Islamic Azad University (IAU), South Tehran/Lahijan Branches, in support of organizing the present research. Also, we appreciate the respected reviewers for their valuable advice on the present manuscript, which has truly helped us in the revision process. At last, special thanks to my dear wife Mrs Maryam Aghaei Sarchali for her efficient assistance, in the process of realizing the present research. This work is investigated under contract with the Research Department of the IAU, South Tehran Branch, Tehran, Iran.

fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
